questions.text: A 6 year old child presented to ENT OPD. The mother is complaining that the child is suffering from hearing loss. The Otoscopy picture is given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The otoscopy picture depicts a retracted tympanic membrane with a dull appearance and a fluid-filled middle ear space behind it. This clinical presentation is indicative of Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), also known as "glue ear." OME occurs when fluid accumulates in the middle ear without acute infection. It is common in young children and can lead to temporary hearing loss due to the restriction of tympanic membrane movement and interference with sound transmission to the inner ear.

Other options:

  1. Pneumo Tympanum - This condition refers to the presence of air in the middle ear cavity, but it is not consistent with the otoscopy image showing fluid-filled middle ear space.
  2. Myringitis Bullosa - Myringitis Bullosa is characterized by the formation of bullae or blisters on the tympanic membrane. The image does not show any bullae or blisters
  3. Acute Suppurative Otitis Media - Acute Suppurative Otitis Media is characterized by the presence of pus in the middle ear due to a bacterial infection. The image does not show signs of active infection with pus formation.

questions.text: A 20 year old male patient presented to ENT OPD with the history of nasal obstruction and severe nasal bleeding. The nasal endoscopy picture shows a mass in the choana as given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The nasal endoscopy picture reveals a reddish, highly vascular mass arising from the posterior nasal cavity and extending into the choana. This clinical presentation is characteristic of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), a benign but locally aggressive tumor that commonly affects young males. It originates from the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity and may cause nasal obstruction, recurrent nosebleeds (epistaxis), and facial pain due to its expansive nature.

Other options:

  1. Inverted Papilloma - Inverted Papilloma is another benign tumor, but it usually arises from the lateral nasal wall or sinuses. It may present with unilateral nasal obstruction and blood-tinged discharge, but its location differs from that seen in the image. It is mainly seen in 40-60 year old age.
  2. Antrochoanal Polyp - An Antrochoanal Polyp is a benign polyp that arises from the maxillary sinus and extends into the choana. However, the characteristic appearance of the tumor in the image is more suggestive of JNA.
  3. Rhinosporidiosis - Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic fungal infection that can cause polypoid growths in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.It presents with Mulberry like mass with epistaxis .

However, the image does not show typical features of this condition.

questions.text: An adult patient while having food suddenly develops a choking sensation and is unable to speak. What is the immediate management
questions.solution:
The described clinical scenario suggests that the patient is experiencing a choking episode due to an obstructed airway caused by food. Heimlich's Maneuver, also known as abdominal thrusts, is the appropriate immediate management for this situation. It involves applying quick inward and upward thrusts to the abdomen to expel the obstructing object from the airway. This technique creates a positive pressure in the chest, forcing the object out and allowing the patient to breath again.


Other options:

  • Chest Back thrusts:This is a first-aid technique that is used to dislodge a foreign object that is blocking a person's airway. The maneuver involves making a fist and placing it between the person's shoulder blades, then forcefully thrusting up.
  • Intubation:This is a medical procedure that is used to insert a tube into the trachea to maintain a person's airway. It is usually performed by a doctor or nurse, and it requires specialized equipment.
  • Cricothyroidotomy:This is a surgical procedure that is used to create an opening in the cricothyroid membrane to maintain a person's airway. It is usually performed in an emergency situation, and it does not require specialized equipment.

questions.text: A patient has developed high frequency sensorineural hearing loss. The cause of hearing loss is found to be due to pathology of the basilar membrane. Which structure lies closest to the site of pathology?
questions.solution:
The basilar membrane is a crucial structure in the cochlea of the inner ear, responsible for frequency tuning and sound perception. High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss indicates damage to the hair cells or nerve fibers in the cochlea that respond to high-frequency sounds. The basilar membrane lies adjacent to the cochlear fluids and is directly involved in the transmission of sound vibrations to the hair cells. The closest structure to the basilar membrane is the oval window, a membrane-covered opening between the middle ear and the cochlea, where the stapes bone transmits sound vibrations.

Other options:

  1. Stria Vascularis - The Stria Vascularis is a highly vascularized structure located in the lateral wall of the cochlear duct. It plays a role in maintaining the endolymphatic potential and is not in close proximity to the basilar membrane.
  2. Modiolus - The Modiolus is the central core of the cochlea, around which the cochlear turns spiral. It provides structural support and contains nerve fibers but is not directly involved in the pathophysiology of high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
  3. Helicotrema - The Helicotrema is the point of communication between the scala vestibuli and the scala tympani at the apex of the cochlea. It is not directly related to the pathology of the basilar membrane.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Basal turn of cochlea senses high frequency sound while apex senses low frequency sound.

questions.text: A adult patient is a known case of bronchial asthma. He has a history of regular medication. The nasal examination shows the presence of nasal polypi. Which drug he is most likely sensitive to?
questions.solution:
The patient's known case of bronchial asthma and the presence of nasal polyp suggest that the patient may have Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), also known as Samter's Triad. AERD is a condition where patients with asthma develop a hypersensitivity reaction to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like Aspirin, leading to exacerbation of respiratory symptoms, including nasal polyps and bronchospasm. It is essential to avoid NSAIDs in such patients as they can trigger severe bronchoconstriction and worsen asthma symptoms.

Other options:

  • Ampicillin:This is a penicillin antibiotic that is commonly used to treat infections. It is not as likely to cause an allergic reaction as aspirin, so it is a less likely option for a patient with nasal polyps.
  • Penicillin:This is another penicillin antibiotic that is commonly used to treat infections. It is also not as likely to cause an allergic reaction as aspirin, so it is a less likely option for a patient with nasal polyps.
  • Erythromycin:This is a macrolide antibiotic that is commonly used to treat infections. It is not a member of the aspirin family, so it is not as likely to cause an allergic reaction as aspirin.

questions.text: A young Diabetic patient has presented to ENT OPD with blood stained nasal discharge, eye involvement and recent history of loose upper teeth. Which of the following is the first investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of blood-stained nasal discharge, eye involvement, and loose upper teeth raises suspicion of an aggressive and locally invasive lesion in the sinonasal region. The first investigation in this case should be an MRI of the head. MRI provides detailed images of the sinonasal structures, including soft tissues, bones, and surrounding structures, and can help identify the extent of the lesion and its relationship to adjacent vital structures. This investigation is crucial for further evaluation and treatment planning.

Other options:

  1. Serum Ferritin Level - This is a blood test that measures the amount of iron stored in the body. It is not a diagnostic test for Wegener's granulomatosis, so it is not the best first investigation.
  2. Glycosylated Hemoglobin Levels - Glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels are used to assess long-term blood glucose control in diabetic patients and are not directly related to the evaluation of sinonasal pathology.
  3. Nasal Swab - It is a test that is used to collect cells from the nose. These cells can then be examined under a microscope to look for signs of infection or inflammation. However, a nasal swab is not a very sensitive test for Wegener's granulomatosis. This is because the disease can often affect the lungs and kidneys, and these areas are not easily accessible with a nasal swab.

questions.text: Identify the bone shown in the image
questions.solution:
The image shows the Incus, which is the second ossicle in the middle ear. The Incus is a small, anvil-shaped bone that connects the Malleus (hammer) to the Stapes (stirrup) and plays a crucial role in transmitting sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear.

Other options:

  1. Malleus: The Malleus, also known as the "hammer," is one of the three small bones (ossicles) located in the middle ear. It is the outermost ossicle and is attached to the tympanic membrane (eardrum). The Malleus is responsible for transmitting sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the next ossicle, the Incus.
  1. Stapes: The Stapes, also known as the "stirrup," is the innermost ossicle in the middle ear. It is the smallest bone in the human body. The Stapes is connected to the Incus on one end and the oval window (a membrane-covered opening to the inner ear) on the other end. It plays a crucial role in transmitting sound vibrations from the middle ear to the fluid-filled cochlea of the inner ear.
  2. Hyoid: The Hyoid bone is a unique U-shaped bone located in the neck, just above the larynx (voice box). It is the only bone in the human body that does not directly articulate with any other bone. The Hyoid bone serves as an attachment site for several muscles involved in swallowing and speaking.
